awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Bioengineering probiotic yeast to mitigate methane emissions from cattle
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project develops a technology that could drastically reduce the impact of livestock production on the environment. Methane emissions from livestock account for over 10% of global greenhouse gas emissions, which must be reduced significantly in order to meet climate change reduction targets. Simultaneously, profit margins in beef and dairy farming are slim, leaving farmers unable to adopt climate-friendly practices that are too costly. This product could increase the profitability of cattle farming while playing a key role in achieving net zero emissions from the food system.

This team develops enzymes to be secreted from a probiotic yeast to eliminate methane emissions from cattle. The company has previously identified a set of enzymes that restrict methane production in the rumen of cattle. This project will further develop and package these enzymes in a probiotic yeast strain which has already been shown to increase milk yield by over 5%, thereby offering a dual benefit to the farmers. Project success requires a) screening an enzyme library to identify lead candidates for reduction of rumen methane, b) optimizing enzymes for further methane reduction, and c) demonstrating enzyme secretion and cost-efficient enzyme delivery by the probiotic yeast. Completion of these objectives will yield a product that will decrease cattle methane emissions by a minimum of 30%, and potentially by up to 98%, while simultaneously improving the health and productivity of cattle.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Hoofprint Biome's Phase I SBIR project aimed to develop a technology that could drastically reduce the impact of livestock production on the environment. Methane emissions from livestock account for over 10% of global greenhouse gas emissions, which must be reduced significantly in order to meet climate change reduction targets. Simultaneously, profit margins in beef and dairy farming are slim, leaving farmers unable to adopt climate-friendly practices that are too costly. 

Hoofprint identified a set of enzymes that naturally restrict methane production in the rumen of the cattle. Over the course of the project, the team prioritized lead candidates for reduction of rumen methane and optimized enzymes for further methane reduction. In parallel, the team began work on scalable enzyme production methods, which are essential for commercial feasibility. The team leveraged their experience in cell-free protein synthesis, protein engineering, artificial rumen fermentation, and yeast engineering in order to advance their project.

The research holds promise for a product that could reduce methane emissions from cattle by at least 30%, and potentially by up to 98%, while also supporting or improving the health and productivity of cattle. Beyond the technical milestones, this work supports broader societal goals. If successful, it will offer farmers and food brands a tool that supports both climate commitments and economic viability. This dual benefit could make climate-smart cattle farming more profitable, helping U.S. farmers adopt sustainable practices without sacrificing margins. The team also engaged in educational efforts, mentoring students and collaborating with global researchers to advance climate-smart agricultural innovation.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2025
Modified by: Scott P Collins
